There’s something special about using AI to learn AI — a bit like the tech teaching you about itself. That’s the kind of meta-learning I think we’ll see more of in the future.

It’s fun, fast, and surprisingly personal. Just give it a try and you will find learning AI much more interesting.

postContent:
𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁; 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗹𝗼𝘄

When people think of AI today, they often jump straight to “agents” — smart systems that can plan, reason, and act. But the truth is, success in AI doesn’t come from agents alone. It comes from designing the right workflow.

𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻’𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗿

Not all tasks need an agent. The type of work matters.
1. Low variance, high standardization
Examples: regulatory disclosures, investor onboarding
Best fit: Rules-based automation + workflow software + predictive models

2. High variance, low standardization
Examples: compliance checks, extracting complex financial data
Best fit: Agentic AI


𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 “𝗔𝗜 𝗦𝗹𝗼𝗽”: 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝘁𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗲𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

If users don’t trust AI, they won’t use it. That’s why we need strong evaluations to measure performance. Some useful evaluation methods include:
- Task success rate: How often does the agent complete the full job correctly without human help?
- F1 score (precision and recall): Useful when classification or decision-making must be accurate.
- Retrieval accuracy: Did the system find the right documents, facts, or evidence?
- Semantic similarity: Does the AI output mean the same thing as the correct reference, even if the words differ?
- LLM-as-judge: Use another model to rate clarity, helpfulness, and soundness of reasoning.
- Bias detection: Check if errors affect one group more than others.
- Hallucination rate: How often does the agent make things up?
- Calibration error: Does the agent’s confidence level match its actual correctness?

𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗹𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗲𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲

It’s not enough to measure results at the end. Every step in the workflow should be monitored and verified.

For eg, if an agent is retrieving data for a compliance check, we need to know:

- Which sources it used
- Whether its confidence was justified
- If it skipped or misread any step

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲

Building agents from scratch for every new workflow is inefficient. A better way is to create a central library of reusable services and assets, such as:

- Pre-approved prompts
- Application patterns
- Reusable code snippets
- Observability tools for LLMs
- Training materials

𝗛𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗹

Even with advanced agents, humans will always be part of the picture. Their role, however, will evolve.

Instead of doing repetitive tasks, humans will supervise, guide, and collaborate with agents. One promising area is human–agent collaborative design, which creates simple interfaces so that non-technical people can interact with AI systems easily.

One that never sleeps, checks every reply, and tells you—in plain English—if it’s good or not.

That’s “LLM-as-a-judge.” One AI grading another, on your rules.

Example: a support bot gets a new “concise and friendly” voice. Instead of reading 2,000 replies, you ask LLM to be “support manager for a day.”

The prompt:

Boom. 87% of answers score 4 or higher. The weak 13%? Refund questions. That’s where you add humans.

Result: you ship faster, learn sooner, and let people focus on the tricky cases.

If your QA plan still says, “we’ll spot-check 50 samples,” maybe it’s time to appoint an AI judge.

postContent:
There’s a common belief that AI will close the skill gap between beginners and experts. But a new Stanford-Harvard study shows it’s more complicated. 

Researchers studied three groups inside an organization, all asked to write web articles:
 • Insiders: SEO web analysts who regularly wrote articles
 • Adjacent outsiders: marketers in the same department who didn’t usually write
 • Distant outsiders: technologists whose work was unrelated to writing 

AI didn’t boost every group equally. It helped adjacent outsiders close the gap and perform at insider level. But distant outsiders (technologists) still fell short. Even with AI fine-tuned on company documents, their articles scored lower than insiders’. They hit what the researchers call the “GenAI wall.” 

They lacked too much of the marketers’ tacit knowledge: the instinct for tone, the craft of building a narrative, the ability to weave ideas coherently, and the judgment of what makes an article “good.” AI couldn’t fill that gap or replicate the intuition that insiders had built through experience.

One of the next big challenges, and opportunities, for AI is learning tacit knowledge. Bridging the gap between novices and experts requires more than data. It means capturing the shortcuts, sequences, and judgment calls that turn a draft into a finished product. 

Only when AI understands the real workflows, rhythms, and processes of an organization can it start to absorb that hidden know-how—and begin to shift the “GenAI wall.”

AI isn’t just about building the future.
Sometimes, it’s about bringing the past back to life. 

Recently, I pulled out some really old family photos.
Faded, scratched, almost torn.
The kind of memories you’re scared to even touch.

I decided to try Google Gemini / Veo to restore and animate them.

At first, it wasn’t perfect.
Faces looked blurry, eyes came out strange, and the colors felt too modern.
But with some trial and error—and the right prompts—things started to change.

Here’s what worked for me:
“Restore old black and white photo, remove scratches, sharpen face details, natural skin tones.”
“Animate portrait — subtle eye blink, gentle smile, natural head movement, realistic lighting.”

And suddenly… that grainy picture of my parents turned sharp, clear, and alive.
When the animation played—eyes blinking, lips moving softly—it felt like time was breathing again.
Honestly, it gave me goosebumps.

For me, this is the real magic of AI.
Not just automation. Not just scale.
But giving forgotten memories a second life.

If you’ve got old photos lying in an album somewhere, maybe let AI give them a little nudge.
You might be surprised how the past comes alive.

A 3-year journey: My kiddo & personal brand 

Three years ago, two journeys began almost at the same time — the birth of my son and the birth of my personal brand.

The first step as parents was naming. My wife and I wanted our son’s name to reflect our values. That clarity made the decision quick. I realise now — conceptualising my brand was the same. Identity comes first and it needs to stem from your deep vision.

Soon, my son started crawling, then walking. Every day was a baby step forward. Some falls, some wins. That’s how a personal brand grows too — small, steady efforts like writing one post, connecting with one person, sharing one idea.

Next came the exploring phase. He began noticing and engaging with things on his own. Some guidance helped, but most of the learning came naturally. My brand also grew this way — not only from planning but also from experiments and surprises.

Then he began running. Chasing what he liked, leaving what he didn’t. I’ve learned to do the same — focusing on work that feels right and letting go of what doesn’t.

Finally came speaking. At first, he repeated words like a parrot. Slowly, his own voice came out. For any brand, this is the most important stage too — moving from copying others to finding your own voice.

Today, as I see my son turning 3, I see my journey reflected in his. 
Growth — whether of a child or a brand — is never instant. It’s made of small steps, curiosity, focus, and finally, a voice that is truly yours.

Both journeys continue to inspire each other. Both remind me: nurturing brings growth, and being authentic brings magic.

While HR industry debates the use of AI in recruitment
The fact of the matter is that AI is already deployed as a gatekeeper in many companies. One that shortlists you for the next human round
Increasingly many of them are video bots too

As a candidate, there are good chances that I might have to face these video bots. 
Definitely these interviews are different from the regular ones in terms of observations and assessments. I have been thinking about aspects which really matter in these interviews.

Here are some useful tips to ace these AI interviews?

1. Learn the filters
AI looks for 3 things:
 •	Voice clarity & tone
 •	Substance in answers
 •	Eye contact & body language

2. STAR method works
 •	Situation
 •	Task
 •	Action
 •	Result
Example (tech): Fixed payment bug in 5 mins during peak traffic.

3. Keywords without stuffing
“I used SEO & analytics to grow traffic by 60% in 4 months.”
and not “I’m great at SEO, marketing, analytics.”

4. Practise your vocal smile
Yes — AI “hears” warmth.
Talk like you’re speaking to a friendly teammate.

5. Look at the lens, not your reflection.

6. If you get a surprise question?
Smile, pause, and say:
“That’s a great question — let me think for a sec.”

7. Balance warmth and precision

8. Be specific with results
“Cut load time from 4s to 1.2s, saving 25% server costs.”
and not “Improved system performance”

9. Practise with mock AI
Try HireVue practice mode or record yourself on Zoom.
Fix tone, pace, and keywords.

postContent:
Love the way how Dharmesh BA 🕵🏽‍♂️ breaks down voice agent conversations

Most companies optimize for speed in simple transactions while fumbling the conversations that actually drive revenue. It's like perfecting your small talk while failing every job interview.

Utility Conversations: This governs the simple stuff: reminders, updates, confirmations. Here, brevity is king. Users want information, not intimacy. Get in, deliver value, get out. No small talk required.

Free Flowing Conversations: This operates in the realm of pure relationship. These are the conversations that serve no transactional purpose but fulfill a deeper human need-the digital equivalent of sitting on a porch, sharing silence with someone you trust. This is where AI companions, therapy bots, and digital astrologers live. The goal isn't efficiency; it's presence.

Persuasive Conversations: This sits in the profitable middle ground between Utility and Free Flowing. This is where the real money lives - every conversation that requires changing minds rather than simply providing information. Loan collections, insurance sales, complex purchases, understanding why someone abandoned their shopping cart. They require something more sophisticated: the ability to build just enough trust to accomplish a specific goal, then gracefully exit.


The companies that crack this code won't just build better voice agents - they'll unlock an entirely new category of digital relationship, one that respects both human psychology and business reality.

postContent:
I read this great post by Paras Chopra on practical tips on building LLM agents and it really clicked. Here are the top lessons I have learnt:

1. Keep tasks small and clear
 •	Break down big goals into simple, sequential steps.
 •	LLMs perform best when each task is focused and can be completed in approximately 10–15 minutes.

2. Rely on one smart agent
 •	Avoid overengineering with multiple agents and complex inter-agent communication.
 •	Equip a single agent with long context and tools so it can work end-to-end.

3. Double-check outputs
 •	Implement a verification step after each task.
 •	Ask agents to check their own work or specify criteria for success or failure, to catch errors early.

4. Remind the agent of its goal
 •	Reinforce the end goal repeatedly, especially in long workflows.
 •	Summarize progress and clarify what remains to be done at each step.

5. Provide tools 
 •	Let your agent read and write files, take notes, and track progress.
 •	Treat giving tools as “adding memory”—this enables agents to maintain continuity and avoid forgetting earlier steps.

6. Never change context in midway (for multi-turn agents)
 •	Keeping a linear, append-only log is simpler, more transparent, and reduces errors.

These strategies help LLM agents move from unpredictable black boxes to dependable, structured teammates in your workflow.

postContent:
Everyone’s excited about speech-to-speech LLMs and heard a lot of ppl working on them but here’s the truth: they’re a lot of work needed to make them usable

1.  Hinglish (or other language mix) + Emotion = ASR nightmare
Even best-in-class ASR models stumble when a user says:
“Sir woh 12k ka auto-debit hua tha na, wo bounce ho gaya.”

Mix of Hindi-English. Local idioms. Numbers. Emotional charge.
If your transcript fails here, your LLM never had a chance.
Now imagine debugging this without even having access to the transcript — because S2S doesn’t give you one.

2. Real-time turn taking

Indian conversations are not “one question, one answer.”
We interrupt. We change tone. We speed up. We get emotional.
S2S systems haven’t figured out real-time turn-taking yet.

3. Fine-tuning needs speech-to-speech data, which we don’t have at scale. 

4. Infra costs are massive

Modular pipelines (ASR → LLM → TTS) still win on control, auditability, and resilience.

postContent:
Partial autonomy LLM apps - a very interesting concept introduced by Andrej Karpathy explained using Perplexity and Cursor

1. Package Context

Capture and condense relevant user state into a context window.
Perplexity: condenses query + source highlights into a prompt.
Cursor: packages current file, cursor location, and error stack into LLM prompt.

2. Orchestrate LLM Calls

Dynamically select and sequence LLMs for different tasks.
Perplexity: summarization + follow-ups + ranking.
Cursor: uses embedding models (for diffing), chat models (for explanation), and diff-apply models.

3. Application-Specific GUI (HUO)

Human-Use Optimization: UI tailored for high signal extraction and minimal friction.
Perplexity: inline sources, follow-up buttons, vertical layout.
Cursor: LLM panel next to editor, accept/suggest fix inline.

4. Autonomy Slider

User can control how much the LLM does:
Search → Research → Deep Research
Suggest fix → Autocomplete fix → Implement fix autonomously

Perplexity: follow-up questions = low autonomy; auto-summaries = higher.
Cursor: Tab → Cmd+K → Cmd+L → Cmd+I shifts toward agent mode.

I’ve been working on conversational voice agents for a while now — and here’s something I’ve learned the hard way:

It’s not the answers that make a agent feel human.
It’s everything between the answers.

It’s about rhythm, timing, and subtle social signals we humans take for granted.

Here’s where most voice agents still fall short:

Can it sense when you’re done speaking — or does it jump the gun and interrupt?
Can it gracefully pause, overlap, or let you finish a sentence without sounding mechanical?
Humans typically respond in ~200 ms. Agents often take seconds… or worse, talk over you.
A 2-second silence can mean respect in one culture, awkwardness in another. Most systems don’t account for that.

Until agents master the unspoken parts of conversation,
they’ll keep sounding like guests at a party who don’t know when to speak — or when to leave.


What’s the most “human” agent you’ve encountered lately?

Valuations are showing it too. Many AI-native startups are getting 3–4x the multiple of similar SaaS counterparts.


The SaaS wave gave us unicorns.

If you’re building something new—don’t bolt AI onto your roadmap.

postContent:
The smartphone industry is undergoing a seismic shift as AI becomes accessible to all. Features like intelligent cameras and voice assistants—once exclusive to expensive flagship devices—are now making their way into affordable smartphones. This transformation is being driven by smaller brands leveraging a new wave of low-cost, AI-capable chipsets.

Chipmakers are at the heart of this revolution, holding the key to reducing the cost of processing AI tasks. The iQOO Neo 10R, powered by the Snapdragon 8s Gen 3, has dominated the mid-range segment since its April 2025 launch, delivering stellar gaming, multitasking, and AI-enhanced performance. Meanwhile, the Vivo T4X, priced under ₹15,000, introduces AI capabilities to budget-conscious buyers with its MediaTek Dimensity 7300 chipset.

So, what’s driving this democratization of AI?

First, Neural Processing Units (NPUs) like MediaTek’s NPU 655 in the Dimensity 7300 double the efficiency of AI tasks, enabling on-device processing for seamless, cloud-independent experiences.

Second, efficient fabrication processes—such as the 4nm technology used in Qualcomm and MediaTek chipsets—pack more power into smaller, energy-efficient designs, making AI viable at lower price points.

Third, optimized open-source AI models tailored for mobile—like Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 6 Gen 4 supporting Meta’s Llama 3.2—allow mid-tier phones to run sophisticated AI applications locally, enhancing both privacy and performance.

As smaller brands continue to adopt these affordable, AI-capable chipsets, the market is rapidly evolving. IDC predicts that 28% of new smartphones will be generative AI-capable by the end of 2025, rising to 58% by 2028. This trend not only fuels innovation but also empowers consumers with AI-driven features—such as smarter photography, real-time translation, and personalized assistants—without breaking the bank.

The future of mobile technology is inclusive, and it’s exciting to see how these advancements will reshape our digital lives.

Jensen Huang explained use of reasoning models in his GTC 2025 keynote speech

He shared below example to highlight 2 distinct approaches to problem-solving in AI systems:

“Arrange seating for a wedding dinner, considering traditions, photogenic angles, and feuding family members.”

Traditional Language Model (Llama 3)
- Generated a seating plan in <500 tokens (result was fast)
- Produced errors due to insufficient reasoning about complex constraints
- Failed to account for nuanced family dynamics and photogenic requirements

Reasoning Model (Deepseek R1)
- Used >8,000 tokens for multi-step analysis
- Identified family conflicts through relationship mapping
- Optimized seating angles for photography sightlines
- Balanced traditional seating protocols with modern preferences
- Performed iterative validation checks on proposed arrangements

Huang emphasized that while reasoning models consume 16x more tokens, they enable:
- Comprehensive constraint analysis
- Solution space exploration
- Self-verification through "digital twin" simulations

This method is super useful for chatbots, research, coding, writing, and even simple Q&A with AI. It helps in:

- Making AI-generated content more useful

Next time you ask AI something, try adding specific keywords—you’ll see the difference!

postContent:
"All models are biased, some are useful." - a very insightful post from Sridhar Vembu on LLM models. Read on

AI models, even "open weight" models like Deepseek are black boxes. 

There are two big unknowns: We do not know what kind of training data went into them and second, we do not know what kind of "reinforcement learning" was done to make them "behave well". 

Here "behave well" includes innocuous things like making the model polite to human users and much more contentious issues like active censorship of ideas the model trainer wants to suppress.

The models reflect the values systems of those that train them.

US trained models show sensitivity in certain areas while Chinese trained models show in other areas. 

In areas like generating code to playing chess, there are objective standards by which we can evaluate models (even here, to give an example, a model could prefer Javascript over C but that is a second order issue). 

This is why I would trust these models only when there are other objective ways to evaluate their output. This is true for fields like programming, computer aided design etc.

I would not trust the AI to give economic development advice - given that I don't find most academic economics useful and these models have memorized the text books and the value-neutral economics they teach. But that is own my bias.

When we deeply reflect on this, we can see that the ultimate model is going to differ from person to person, and that personal model will train itself on the person's own system of values, acting as a faithful mirror of their thinking process.

postContent:
How to build India specific LLM.. here are very interesting views shared by @bookwormengr on X

AI is not hard 
————————————
Many teams that built foundation models are below 50 ppl (e.g. Mixtral). 
In AI, LLM science part is actually quite easy. 
All these models are “Transformer Decoder only models”, an architecture that was invented in late 2017. 
There are improvements since then (flash attention, ROPE, MOE, PPO/DPO/GRPO), but they are relatively minor, open source and easy to implement. 

Since building foundation models is easy and Nvidia is there to help you (if not directly, then by sharing their software like “Megatron” that is assembly line to build AI models) there are so many foundation models built by Chinese labs as well as global labs.

It is machines that learn by themselves…if you give them data & compute. This is unlike writing operating system or database software. Also, everyone trains on same data: internet archives, books, github code for the first stage called “pre-training”.

What is part is hard then?
———————————-
It is the parallel & distributed computing to run AI training jobs across thousands of GPUs that is hard. DeepSeek did lot of innovation here to save on “flops” and network calls. They used an innovative architecture called Mixture of Experts and a new approach called GRPO. with verifiable rewards both of which are in open domain through 2024.

Also, there is lot of data curation needed particularly for “post training”
to teach model on proper style of answering (SFT/DPO) or to teach them learn to reason (GRPO with verifiable reward). SFT/DPO is where “stealing” from existing models to save cost of manual labor may happen.

LLM building is nothing that Indian engineers living in India cannot pull off. Don’t worry about Indians who have left. There are plenty in the country as of today. 

Then why India does not have foundation models?
———————
It is for the same reason India does not have Google or Facebook of its own. 

You need to able to walk before you can run.

There is no protected market to practice your craft in early days. You will get replaced by American service providers as they are cheaper and better every single time. That is not the case with Chinese player. They have a protected market and leadership who treats this skillset as existential due to geopolitics. 

So, even if Chinese models are not good in early days they will continue to get funding from their conglomerates as well as provincial governments. Darwinian competition ensures best rise to the top.

Recall DeepSeek took 2 years to get here without much revenue. They were funded by their parent. Also, most of their engineers are not PHDs.

There is nothing that engineers who built Ola/Swiggy/Flipkart cannot build. Remember these services are second to none when you compare them to their Bay Area counterparts. Also , don’t trivialize those services; there is brilliant engineering to make them work at the price points at which they work.

✅ Standard (60-80%): For compliance, accuracy, and consistency. Think legal disclosures, account details, and FAQs.
🤖 Generated (20-40%): For empathy, personalization, and dynamic problem-solving. Perfect for offering flexible options or answering unstructured queries.

Gen AI isn’t a one-size-fits-all solution to all problems. Many problems don’t even need AI.

𝟮. 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗳𝘂𝘀𝗲 ‘𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁’ 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 ‘𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗔𝗜’
For many AI product, AI is the easy part, product is the hard part.

𝟲. 𝗖𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗱𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲𝘀

Customer Query: “I’ve been charged twice for my subscription, and I was promised a discount last month, but it wasn’t applied. Can you help?”

The system immediately:
1. Retrieve Data:
 •	Fetches the customer’s billing history.
 •	Locates the transcript of the previous promise of a discount.
 •	Retrieves the company’s policy on handling duplicate charges.

2. Analyze and Summarize:
 •	Identifies the root issue: a duplicate charge and a missing discount.
 •	Checks whether the duplicate charge has already been refunded or is pending.
 •	Flags discrepancies in how the discount was handled.

3. Generate Suggestions for Resolution:
Prepares multiple actionable solutions:
 •	Refund one of the duplicate charges.
 •	Apply the promised discount retroactively.
 •	Offer additional compensation for the inconvenience (e.g., a credit).

Five lessons for enterprises from McKinsey’s own LLM development

1. Prompt matters - a lot 
Effective prompt engineering requires collaboration between domain experts and technical teams, treating it as an iterative, artistic process rather than a rigid scientific approach.

2. Be vigilant about data curation 
Not all organizational data is equally valuable; strategic data selection is crucial for controlling costs and maximizing the quality of generative AI outputs.

3. Invest in an orchestration layer 
A sophisticated routing mechanism can help overcome LLM limitations by intelligently selecting the most appropriate model for specific tasks, improving both performance and cost-efficiency.

4. Test and test again - and again 
Proactive testing with active learning loops is essential in generative AI development, allowing quick detection and correction of potential issues like model hallucinations or misunderstood intents.

5. It's never just tech 
Successful AI adoption requires a holistic approach that goes beyond technology, focusing on user experience, continuous learning, leadership engagement, and adaptive support mechanisms.

postContent:
Imagine trying to get a workout recommendation while running, navigate a complex route while driving, or get tech support while cooking - all without touching a screen. This is the promise of voice-enabled LLM agents, a technological leap that's redefining how we interact with machines.

Traditional text-based chatbots are like trying to dance with two left feet. They're clunky, impersonal, and frustratingly limited. Consider these real-world friction points:
- A visually impaired user struggling to type support queries
- A fitness enthusiast unable to get real-time guidance mid-workout
- A busy professional multitasking who can't pause to type a complex question

Voice AI breaks these barriers, mimicking how humans have communicated for millennia. We learn to speak by four months, but writing takes years - testament to speech's fundamental naturalness.

Real-World Transformation Examples:
1️⃣ Healthcare: Emotion-recognizing AI can detect patient stress levels through voice modulation, enabling more empathetic remote consultations.
2️⃣ Fitness: Hands-free coaching that adapts workout intensity based on your breathing and vocal energy.
3️⃣ Customer Service: Intelligent voice systems that understand context, emotional undertones, and personalize responses in real-time.

The magic of voice lies in its nuanced communication:
- Tone reveals emotional landscapes
- Intensity signals urgency or excitement
- Rhythm creates conversational flow
- Inflection adds layers of meaning beyond mere words
- Recognize emotional states with unprecedented accuracy
- Support rich, multimodal interactions combining voice, visuals, and context
- Differentiate speakers in complex conversations
- Extract subtle contextual intentions
- Provide personalized responses based on voice characteristics

In short, this technology is about creating more human-centric technology that listens, understands, and responds like a thoughtful companion.

The future of AI isn't about machines talking at us, but talking with us.
